Eve gittiğimde, annem ve babamla konuşmaya karar verdim. Onlara her şeyi anlattım ve yardım istemeye karar verdim. Onlar da bana yardım etmeye karar verdiler ve birlikte bir plan yaptık. Ben değişime başladım ve yeni şeyler denemeye başladım. Okulda daha çok çalışmaya başladım ve notlarım yavaş yavaş yükselmeye başladı. Annem ve babam da bana daha çok destek olmaya başladılar. Ben değişime devam ettim ve sonunda başarılı oldum. Artık notlarım iyi ve mutluyum.

en_first_half: The next afternoon, as I was leaving the three-hour Latin exam, my eyes swimming
en_second_half: with all the Greek and Roman names I’d misspelled, Mr. Brunner called me back inside.
en_results: with tears of relief, I stumbled upon a flyer advertising a summer program in Rome. The
en_results_raw: with tears of relief, I stumbled upon a flyer advertising a summer program in Rome. The program promised an immersive experience, with students living with local families and attending daily language classes. I felt an inexplicable pull towards the idea of spending my summer in the Eternal City, surrounded by the history and culture that I had only read about in textbooks. Without hesitation, I ripped off a tab from the flyer with the program's website and shoved it into my pocket, already envisioning myself wandering along the Tiber Island and sipping espresso at a charming café in Piazza Navona. Little did I know, this impulsive decision would be the start of a life-changing adventure that would challenge my perceptions, test my courage, and forever alter the course of my life.

en_first_half: I felt angry at my father. Maybe it was stupid, but I resented him for going on that ocean voyage,
en_second_half: for not having the guts to marry my mom. He’d left us, and now we were stuck with Smelly Gabe.
en_results: and for leaving me behind, even though I knew it was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for him.
en_results_raw: and for leaving me behind, even though I knew it was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for him. I had always been fascinated by the sea, and the thought of exploring its depths and discovering new worlds was a tantalizing prospect. But my father had deemed me too young, too inexperienced, and had instead chosen to take my older brother, James, with him on the journey. I felt a pang of jealousy and resentment towards James, who had always been the favored son, the one who got to do all the exciting things while I was left behind to mind the mundane tasks. I wondered if I would ever get the chance to prove myself, to show my father that I was capable of more than just helping with the household chores. As I sat in my room, feeling sorry for myself, I heard a knock at the door. It was my mother, come to try and cheer me up, no doubt. But I wasn't in the mood for her gentle words and soothing smiles. I just wanted to be left alone, to wallow in my own misery. But as I looked up at her, I saw something in her eyes that gave me pause. A glimmer of understanding, of knowing. And in that moment, I felt a sense of connection to her, a sense of solidarity. Maybe, just maybe, she understood me better than I thought.

es_results_raw: que me había hablado de la belleza de la costa de Long Island, y cómo la lluvia y la oscuridad podían transformar completamente el paisaje. Me pregunté si ella habría visto alguna vez un paisaje así, tan desierto y solitario. De repente, recordé la vez que habíamos ido juntos a la playa, cuando el sol brillaba y el mar estaba en calma. ¡Qué contraste con el paisaje que teníamos enfrente! La lluvia caía con tanta fuerza que apenas podíamos ver a unos metros de distancia. Los árboles se sacudían con violencia, y el viento aullaba como un lobo herido. Era como si la naturaleza misma estuviera en guerra consigo misma. Pero, a pesar de la tempestad, había algo hermoso en el paisaje. La lluvia creaba un velo de misterio que envolvía todo, y la oscuridad parecía tener una profundidad que no habíamos visto antes. Era como si el paisaje estuviera vivo, y estuviera cambiando ante nuestros ojos.

es_second_half: La segunda vez me envió aquí. A la colina Mestiza. Un campamento de verano para mocosos como tú. «Será mejor influencia. Trabajarás con jóvenes en lugar de despedazarlos», me dijo. ¡Ja! Es totalmente injusto.
es_results: La tercera vez, me castigó con una tarea que me pareció imposible: debía escribir un ensayo sobre la importancia de la obediencia. Me costó mucho, pero finalmente lo logré. Sin embargo, no pude evitar sentir que
es_results_raw: La tercera vez, me castigó con una tarea que me pareció imposible: debía escribir un ensayo sobre la importancia de la obediencia. Me costó mucho, pero finalmente lo logré. en_results_raw: you'd expect. I tried to struggle, but she was too strong. My face was inches from the murky water when I heard the sound of footsteps coming from the hallway. Clarisse froze, her grip on my hair tightening. The footsteps stopped right outside the door, and I could sense a presence looming over us. Suddenly, the door creaked open, and a low, gravelly voice spoke up, "What's going on here?" Clarisse slowly stood up, releasing her grip on my hair, and I took a step back, gasping for air. I turned to face the newcomer, and my eyes widened in shock as I took in the sight of a towering figure clad in a long, black coat, his face obscured by the shadows. Clarisse seemed to shrink away, her eyes darting nervously between the stranger and me. "Just a little... disagreement," she stammered. The stranger's gaze lingered on me before shifting to Clarisse, his expression unreadable. "I think it's time for me to take over," he said, his voice low and menacing. Clarisse nodded hastily, backing away as the stranger stepped forward, his eyes fixed on me with an unnerving intensity. I tried to take a step back, but my legs felt like lead, rooted to the spot. The stranger's gaze seemed to bore into my soul, and I felt a shiver run down my spine as he reached out a gloved hand and grasped my wrist, his grip like a vice. "Let's get out of here," he growled, pulling me toward the door. I stumbled after him, my heart racing with fear, as we left Clarisse and the dingy bathroom behind.

Me sentí un poco incómodo con esto, ya que no quería que la verdad se distorsionara, pero al mismo tiempo, me daba cuenta de que la historia había tomado una vida propia y que ya no podía controlarla.

I walked around the park, following the delicious smell, until I found a small barbecue stand tucked away in a corner. The man running it greeted me with a warm smile and asked what I wanted. I ordered a pulled pork sandwich and a side of coleslaw, and he handed it over to me in a matter of minutes. I took a big bite, and the flavors exploded in my mouth. The pork was tender and juicy, and the coleslaw added a nice crunch and coolness to the dish. I was in heaven. As I was eating, I heard the sound of music coming from the stage, and I knew the festivities were about to begin. I finished my food quickly and made my way back to Annabeth, who was saving us a spot right in front of the stage. We sat down just as the emcee was introducing the first band, and the crowd erupted in cheers. The night was going to be amazing.

en_results_raw: at the edge of the forest, her eyes scanning the trees as if searching for something or someone. I shifted uncomfortably, feeling a bead of sweat trickle down my spine. The air was heavy with the scent of blooming flowers and the distant tang of smoke. Annabeth's grip on my arm tightened, her fingers digging into my skin. "What are we waiting for?" I whispered, trying to keep my voice low. She didn't respond, her gaze fixed on some point beyond the trees. I followed her line of sight, but saw nothing but the dark shapes of the forest, the flickering fireflies, and the occasional hoot of an owl in the distance. Suddenly, Annabeth's head snapped back towards me, her eyes locking onto mine with an intensity that made my heart skip a beat. "It's time," she whispered, her voice barely audible over the sound of crickets. "Let's go."

en_results: asked her a question, she would pause, lost in thought, before responding. I couldn't
en_results_raw: asked her a question, she would pause, lost in thought, before responding. I couldn't help but notice the faint creases on her forehead, a sign of worry that I had never seen before. Her usual enthusiasm for teaching was still there, but it was now tempered with a sense of unease. I tried to brush it off as mere paranoia, but the feeling persisted, like a nagging voice in the back of my mind. One morning, as we sat on the porch, pouring over a particularly tricky passage of Homer, I decided to confront her. "Annabeth, is everything okay?" I asked, trying to sound nonchalant. She looked up, startled, and for a moment, I saw a flicker of fear in her eyes. Then, just as quickly, it was gone, replaced by her usual calm demeanor. "Of course, Percy," she said, smiling. "Why would you ask that?" But I knew what I had seen, and I knew that something was wrong.

I knew that I had to be strong, that I had to be able to take care of myself, no matter what. I thought about all the times that my mom had told me to be strong, to be independent, and I knew that this was one of those times. I squared my shoulders and started to think, to come up with a plan, to figure out what to do next.

Cô ấy nhìn thấy tôi, liền mỉm cười và nói: "Chào anh, anh đến đây để làm gì?" Tôi liền trả lời: "Em ơi, tôi đến đây để tìm kiếm một thứ gì đó." Cô ấy hỏi: "À, anh tìm kiếm cái gì?" Cô ấy nói: "Hạnh phúc là khi anh tìm được điều anh mong muốn, và sống một cuộc sống ý nghĩa." Tôi liền hỏi: "Vậy làm thế nào để tìm được điều mình mong muốn?" Cô ấy nói: "À, điều đó tùy thuộc vào anh. Anh phải tự tìm ra con đường của mình." Tôi liền cảm ơn cô ấy và tiếp tục trên con đường của mình.

Yo no le hice caso, pensando que era solo una amenaza vacía. Pero ella era una mujer muy poderosa y tenía contactos con fuerzas oscuras. Una noche, mientras yo estaba sola en mi casa, ella se apareció y me lanzó un hechizo. Yo me desperté al día siguiente sintiéndome muy mal y con un dolor en el corazón. Mi novio se preocupó mucho por mí y me llevó a ver a un médico, pero nadie pudo descubrir qué me pasaba. Pasaron los días y yo me fui sintiendo peor y peor, hasta que un día mi novio desapareció. Yo lo busqué por todas partes, pero nadie lo había visto. Fue entonces cuando supe que la mala mujer había cumplido su amenaza y se lo había llevado. Yo me quedé sola y desesperada, sin saber qué hacer. Pero entonces recordé las palabras de mi abuela, que me había dicho que siempre había que luchar contra el mal y no rendirse nunca. en_second_half: in two major fights the very first day out from camp. At this rate, we’d never make it to L.A. alive, much less before the summer solstice.
en_results: stranded in the middle of nowhere. I was angry with myself for not being able to protect my friends, for not being able to control my powers.
en_results_raw: stranded in the middle of nowhere. I was angry with myself for not being able to protect my friends, for not being able to control my powers. I was angry with the whole world for being so unfair. I kicked a rock in frustration, watching as it sailed through the air, feeling a small sense of satisfaction as it crashed to the ground. But it wasn't enough. I needed to do something more, to release all this pent-up energy and emotion. I looked around, my eyes settling on a nearby tree. I strode over to it, my fists clenched, and punched it as hard as I could. The tree shuddered under the impact, but it didn't break. I punched it again and again, feeling a small sense of relief with each hit. But it wasn't enough. I needed to do more. I needed to destroy something, to break it into a million pieces. I looked around, my eyes settling on a nearby boulder. I strode over to it, my fists clenched, and lifted it up, feeling its weight in my hands. I threw it to the ground, watching as it shattered into a million pieces. I felt a sense of satisfaction, of relief, but it was short-lived. I knew I couldn't stay here, I had to keep moving. I had to find a way to get us out of this place, to get us back on track. I took a deep breath, trying to calm myself down, trying to think clearly. I looked around, trying to get my bearings. I knew we had to keep moving east, we had to find a way to get back to the road. I started walking, my eyes scanning the horizon, looking for any sign of civilization. I knew it wouldn't be easy, but I was determined. I was determined to get us out of this place, to get us back home.

en_first_half: I waded toward Riptide and grabbed it by the hilt. The Chimera might still be up there with its snaky, fat mother, waiting to finish me off. At
en_second_half: the very least, the mortal police would be arriving, trying to figure out who had blown a hole in the Arch. If they found me, they’d have some questions.
en_results: least I had Riptide now. I held it up, and the familiar surge of power and knowledge flooded through me. I could feel the weight of the sword's history, the
en_results_raw: least I had Riptide now. I held it up, and the familiar surge of power and knowledge flooded through me. I could feel the weight of the sword's history, the countless battles it had been in, the lives it had taken. I felt a sense of calm wash over me, a sense of purpose. I knew what I had to do. I had to get out of there, to find a way back to the village and warn them about the Chimera. I took a deep breath, mentally preparing myself for the journey ahead. I would have to be careful, the Chimera could still be lurking, waiting for its chance to strike. I slowly made my way back down the mountain, my senses on high alert, Riptide at the ready. As I walked, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being watched, that unblinking eyes were trained on me, waiting for me to let my guard down. I kept moving, my heart pounding in my chest, until I finally saw the village in the distance. I quickened my pace, relief washing over me as I saw the familiar buildings, the people going about their daily business. I had made it. I had survived the mountain, and I had Riptide. Now, all I had to do was warn the villagers, and we could start making plans to deal with the Chimera once and for all.

en_results_raw: As we pushed off from the dock, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease wash over me. The spiders, though seemingly harmless, had an unnerving way of moving in unison, their beady eyes glinting in the fading light. Annabeth, sensing my tension, placed a reassuring hand on my arm, her voice low and soothing as she spoke, "It's alright, we'll be fine. We just need to get out of here before things get any worse." I took a deep breath, grasped the small vial of liquid and tossed it into the air. The spiders, sensing something was amiss, paused for a split second, giving me just enough time to grab Sarah's hand and make a run for the door. We burst through it, slamming it shut behind us and leaning against it to block the spiders' pursuit. We didn't stop running until we were back in the safety of our car, speeding away from the infested building as fast as we could. It wasn't until we were several blocks away that we finally felt safe enough to slow down and catch our breath. "What was that stuff?" Sarah asked, still trying to process what had just happened. I hesitated, unsure of how much to reveal. "Just something I found," I said finally, trying to brush it off. But Sarah's eyes narrowed, her expression skeptical. She knew I was hiding something, and I knew she wouldn't let it go until she got the truth out of me.

Who would have thought that Grover, of all people, would be the one to finally find some measure of peace? And what did it mean, really, that he had found it in this place, surrounded by the remnants of a long-forgotten civilization? I didn't have any answers, but I couldn't shake the feeling that something important had just happened, something that would have far-reaching consequences.

en_first_half: “So if the gods fight,” I said, “will things line up the
en_second_half: way they did with the Trojan War? Will it be Athena versus Poseidon?”
en_results: way they do in the stories, with the forces of good on one side and the
en_results_raw: way they do in the stories, with the forces of good on one side and the forces of evil on the other, or will it be more complicated than that?” I asked, my curiosity getting the better of me. The old man chuckled and shook his head, his eyes glinting with amusement. “Ah, my young friend,” he said, “the gods are not so easily categorized as good or evil. They are complex beings, with their own motivations and desires, and their conflicts are rarely so simple as a struggle between light and darkness.” He paused, studying me intently. “But I think you will see, soon enough, that the gods are not the only ones who are complicated. The world itself is full of contradictions, and the forces that shape it are not always what they seem.”

en_first_half: Just as Maurice was poking his head back inside to check out the noise, the zebra leaped over him and into the street. There was yelling and screaming and cars honking. We rushed
en_second_half: to the doors of the trailer in time to see the zebra galloping down a wide boulevard lined with hotels and casinos and neon signs. We’d just released a zebra in Las Vegas.
en_results: to the scene, trying to make sense of the chaos. People were running in all directions, trying to get out of the way of the zebra, which was now galloping down the middle of
en_results_raw: to the scene, trying to make sense of the chaos. People were running in all directions, trying to get out of the way of the zebra, which was now galloping down the middle of the street. Cars were swerving to avoid it, and horns were blaring. I grabbed Maurice's arm and pulled him out of the way just in time, as the zebra thundered past us, its black and white stripes a blur. We watched in amazement as it ran down the street, causing pandemonium wherever it went. Finally, it turned a corner and disappeared from view, leaving behind a trail of confusion and excitement. The crowd that had gathered began to disperse, and we were left standing there, trying to process what had just happened. "Well, that was certainly unexpected," Maurice said, shaking his head. I couldn't help but laugh at the absurdity of it all. "Definitely a first," I agreed. We stood there for a moment, grinning at each other, before Maurice spoke up again. "You know, I think we should follow it. See where it goes." I raised an eyebrow, but he just shrugged. "Why not? It's not every day you get to chase a zebra through the city." I couldn't argue with that, so we set off after the zebra, ready for whatever adventures lay ahead.

The driver, a grizzled old man with a face like worn leather, glanced in the rearview mirror, his eyes glinting with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. He had been driving through these desolate lands for nigh on twenty years, but he still couldn't shake the feeling that he was being watched, that unblinking eyes were trained on him from the shadows. The passenger, a young woman with a look of determination etched on her face, sat rigidly, her hands clenched into fists, her gaze fixed on some point beyond the horizon. She had hired him to take her to the old abandoned mine on the outskirts of town, a place where the locals whispered of ghostly apparitions and unexplained occurrences. The driver had tried to warn her, to tell her of the dangers that lurked in the darkness, but she had just smiled, a cold, mirthless smile, and told him to drive on.

en_first_half: He counted our golden coins into his pouch, then took up his pole. He warbled something
en_second_half: that sounded like a Barry Manilow song as he ferried the empty barge back across the river.
en_results: and began to walk away, his long strides eating up the distance as he disappeared into the crowded
en_results_raw: and began to walk away, his long strides eating up the distance as he disappeared into the crowded market. I watched him go, a mixture of relief and curiosity swirling in my chest. What had just happened? And who was that mysterious stranger, anyway? I turned to my companion, a questioning look on my face, but she just shook her head and shrugged. "No idea," she said, "but I think we just got a good deal." I nodded, tucking the small pouch of silver coins into my belt and adjusting my pack. We had been traveling for weeks, and every bit of coin counted. I glanced around the market, taking in the sights and sounds of the bustling crowd. We needed to find a place to rest for the night, and maybe gather some information about the road ahead. The sun was already high overhead, and I could feel the weight of our journey settling onto my shoulders. I took a deep breath, shouldering my pack, and set off into the crowd, my companion close behind.

Ông Hai nhìn lão ta rồi nói: "Lão đang đan lưới bắt cá, lão có muốn giúp ông không?" Lão ta gật đầu và nói: "Dạ, lão muốn giúp ông." Ông Hai liền đưa cho lão ta một chiếc lưới và nói: "Lão hãy đi bắt cá ở ao kia, ông sẽ đan lưới này." Lão ta cầm lưới và đi đến ao, lão ta thấy rất nhiều cá, lão ta liền bắt cá và bỏ vào giỏ. Khi lão ta bắt được nhiều cá, lão ta liền quay lại và đưa giỏ cá cho ông Hai. Ông Hai nhìn giỏ cá và nói: "Cảm ơn lão, lão đã giúp ông rất nhiều." Lão ta mỉm cười và nói: "Không có vấn đề, ông Hai. Lão vui vì được giúp ông." Ông Hai nhìn lão ta và nói: "Lão là một người rất tốt, lão luôn sẵn sàng giúp đỡ người khác." Lão ta cảm thấy rất vui khi được ông Hai khen ngợi.

en_first_half: I was sure Grover was going to barrel straight through the gates of Hades’s palace,
en_second_half: but his shoes veered sharply to the right and dragged him in the opposite direction.
en_results: but instead, he veered sharply to the left, narrowly avoiding a collision with the gleaming
en_results_raw: but instead, he veered sharply to the left, narrowly avoiding a collision with the gleaming black marble pillars that flanked the entrance. As he sped past, the sound of screeching wheels and burning rubber echoed off the cold stone walls, causing the three-headed dog, Cerberus, to raise its ears in alarm. The beast's eyes, glowing like embers, followed Grover's car as it careened around the corner of the palace, heading straight for the dark and ominous-looking forest that loomed beyond.

Todos los invitados se dieron vuelta para mirarlo, esperando a ver que pasaba. Grover parecia haberse olvidado de su plan original y ahora estaba mas interesado en examinar el lugar. Se acerco a una de las paredes y comenzo a estudiar un cuadro que colgaba alli, como si fuera la cosa mas fascinante que hubiera visto en su vida. La gente comenzo a murmurar y a hacer conjeturas sobre que podria estar pasando por la mente de Grover. Algunos pensaban que habia perdido la cabeza, mientras que otros creian que estaba tramando algo. Pero Grover simplemente seguia alli, inmobil, con la mirada fija en el cuadro.

en_first_half: Hades raised an eyebrow. When he sat forward in his throne, shadowy faces appeared in the folds of his black robes, faces of torment, as if the garment were stitched of trapped souls from the Fields of Punishment,
en_second_half: trying to get out. The ADHD part of me wondered, off-task, whether the rest of his clothes were made the same way. What horrible things would you have to do in your life to get woven into Hades’s underwear?
en_results: As he leaned forward, the faces seemed to writhe in agony, their mouths open in silent screams. The air around him grew colder, heavy with the weight of the underworld. Hades' eyes gleamed with an otherworldly
en_results_raw: As he leaned forward, the faces seemed to writhe in agony, their mouths open in silent screams. The air around him grew colder, heavy with the weight of the underworld. Hades' eyes gleamed with an otherworldly intensity, his gaze piercing the darkness as if searching for something, or someone. The shadows on the walls appeared to twist and writhe, like living things, as if they too were being drawn into the vortex of his power. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the soft whisper of the river Styx, its waters flowing sluggishly through the caverns like a dark, lifeless vein. And then, in the distance, a faint whisper began to echo through the halls, a soft, mournful cry that seemed to come from all directions at once, a sound that sent shivers down the spines of even the most hardened denizens of the underworld.

es_first_half: Hades levantó una ceja. Cuando se inclinó hacia delante, en los pliegues de su túnica aparecieron rostros en sombra, rostros atormentados, como si la prenda estuviera hecha de almas atrapadas en los Campos de Castigo que intentaran escapar.
es_second_half: La parte de mí afectada por el THDA se preguntó, distraída, si el resto de su ropa estaría hecho del mismo modo. ¿Qué cosas horribles había que hacer en la vida para acabar convertido en ropa interior de Hades?
es_results: Los rostros se desvanecieron cuando Hades se enderezó, pero el dios sabía que estaban allí, observándolo, esperando su oportunidad para escapar. La prenda de Hades era un recordatorio constante de su papel como
es_results_raw: Los rostros se desvanecieron cuando Hades se enderezó, pero el dios sabía que estaban allí, observándolo, esperando su oportunidad para escapar. La prenda de Hades era un recordatorio constante de su papel como señor del inframundo, y él la llevaba con orgullo. Sin embargo, en momentos como esos, cuando los rostros en la sombra se manifestaban, Hades no podía evitar sentir un escalofrío en la espalda. Era un recordatorio de que, a pesar de su poder, todavía había aquellos que se atrevían a desafiarlo. Con un gesto brusco, Hades se despojó de la prenda y la lanzó a un lado, revelando su torso musculoso. Los rostros en la sombra se desvanecieron, y el dios se sintió más aliviado. Pero sabía que la prenda siempre estaría allí, esperando por él, recordándolo de sus responsabilidades y de los peligros que acechaban en el inframundo.

en_results_raw: confront the skeletons. The air was filled with the sound of screeching and the stench of decay as the two groups clashed in a flurry of bony fists and snapping jaws. The Furies, their long hair whipping wildly about their faces, unleashed a torrent of curses and shrieks that sent the skeletons stumbling backward. But the undead warriors quickly regained their footing and launched a counterattack, their bony fingers closing around the Furies like vice grips. The three goddesses struggled and kicked, but they were no match for the relentless onslaught of the skeletons. Just as all seemed lost, a blinding light illuminated the battlefield, and the skeletons froze, their jaws agape, as a figure emerged from the radiance. It was a woman, tall and stately, with long golden hair and eyes that shone like the stars. She raised a hand, and the skeletons crumpled to the ground, their bones shattering into a thousand pieces. The Furies, freed from their grasp, hovered in the air, their faces twisted in a mixture of fear and awe. "Who are you?" they whispered in unison. The woman smiled, and her eyes gleamed with a fierce inner light. "I am the one who has been awakened," she said, her voice like music. "And I have come to claim this world as my own."

en_first_half: It’s funny how humans can wrap their mind around things and fit them into their version of
en_second_half: reality. Chiron had told me that long ago. As usual, I didn’t appreciate his wisdom until much later.
en_results: reality. It's as if their brains are constantly trying to make sense of the world, even when it doesn't
en_results_raw: reality. It's as if their brains are constantly trying to make sense of the world, even when it doesn't make sense at all. They'll take a concept, no matter how abstract or illogical, and mold it into something that fits their own personal narrative. It's a remarkable ability, really - the ability to take chaos and turn it into order, to take the unknown and make it known. But it's also a limiting one, because in doing so, they often miss out on the beauty of the unknown, the magic of the unexplained. They get so caught up in their own versions of reality that they forget that there's a whole world out there that doesn't fit into their neat little boxes. And that's where the real magic happens - in the spaces between the boxes, in the unknown, in the unexplained.

en_second_half: outside her diner, gotten a friend to take a photo, and notified the police. Finally, brave Percy Jackson (I was beginning to like this kid) had stolen a gun from his captor in Los Angeles and battled him shotgun-to-rifle on the beach. Police had arrived just in time. But in the spectacular explosion, five police cars had been destroyed and the captor had fled. No fatalities had occurred. Percy Jackson and his two friends were safely in police custody.

es_first_half: Después de todo, el pobrecito Percy Jackson no era un criminal internacional. Había causado un buen revuelo en el autobús Greyhound de Nueva Jersey al intentar escapar de su captor (a posteriori hubo testigos que aseguraron haber visto al hombre vestido de cuero en el autobús: «¿Por qué no lo recordé antes?»). El psicópata había provocado la explosión en el arco de San Luis; ningún chaval habría podido hacer algo así. Una camarera de Denver había visto al hombre amenazar a sus secuestrados delante de su restaurante,
es_second_half: había pedido a un amigo que tomara una foto y lo había notificado a la policía. Al final, el valiente Percy Jackson (empezaba a gustarme aquel chaval) se había hecho con un arma de su captor en Los Ángeles y se había enfrentado a él en la playa. La policía había llegado a tiempo. Pero en la espectacular explosión cinco coches de policía habían resultado destruidos y el secuestrador había huido. No había habido bajas. Percy Jackson y sus dos amigos estaban a salvo bajo custodia policial.
es_results: y había habido un testigo en el aeropuerto de Chicago que había visto al secuestrador de Percy, el hombre de cuero, amenazar a un policía. I threw off the covers and got out of bed, my legs shaking slightly as I made my way to the bathroom. I splashed some water on my face, hoping it would wash away the remnants of the nightmare that still lingered in my mind. But as I looked at my reflection in the mirror, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. My eyes looked sunken, my skin pale, and my hair a tangled mess. I looked like I had been through a war, not just a bad dream. I took a deep breath and tried to shake off the feeling of vulnerability that had settled over me like a shroud. I had to be strong, for myself, for my family, for everyone who was counting on me. I couldn't let one bad dream bring me down. I had to keep moving forward, no matter how hard it seemed.
